<p>PizzaOverhead’s <a href="http://bit.ly/ZnsQyi"><strong>KERBTRACK</strong></a> allows you to look around in-game using your head and a webcam partnered with FreeTrack, FaceTrackNoIR, a TrackIR camera or the Oculus Rift. Use your own head to control several degrees of movement both in and out of IVA.</p>

<p>To find out more about <a href="http://bit.ly/1m9FHOX"><strong>KerbTrack</strong></a>, go <a href="http://bit.ly/ZnsQyi"><strong>HERE</strong></a>.</p>
Darn, I eagerly clicked this thinking it was a kerbal racetrack.

FYI, you have to break your webcam to do stuff like this. There are filters on the cam that have to be removed, and even then it has to be a better quality cam to be compatible. You are better off just paying for the TrackIR hardware if that is what you want. Nevertheless, if your still interested you can check out the Freetrack website on how to tear apart your webcam. Some of them do have software removable filters, those are more expensive. Oh and laptop web cams, just forget it.

Edited September 16, 2014 by Alshain

FacetracknoIR doesn't require breaking anything on the camera. I'm not sure what you're thinking - are you talking about hardware or software filters?

I haven't used freetrack, but facetracknoIR uses facial recognition software to identify eyes, nose, chin - and then tracks the movement of those as you turn your head. It just needs the basic video feed from a camera with a clear enough picture.

FacetracknoIR doesn't require breaking anything on the camera. I'm not sure what you're thinking - are you talking about hardware or software filters?

I haven't used freetrack, but facetracknoIR uses facial recognition software to identify eyes, nose, chin - and then tracks the movement of those as you turn your head. It just needs the basic video feed from a camera with a clear enough picture.

Freetrack requires you remove the IR filters, which are usually physical but if your using an actual video camera and not a webcam, it's often a nightmode setting. It uses LED's to track rather than facial recognition. Sometimes the filter is just unscrewing the lens and can be remove/replaced easily. Other times you have to remove it forcibly and permanently, it depends on the camera. FacetracknoIR does not need this, you are correct, however it's not as accurate in tracking as Freetrack. Though to be honest, I'm not sure for THIS game accuracy matters. I have not tried it in KSP since I do have a TrackIR now I probably won't bother.

Supposedly FacetracknoIR uses a lot of CPU also, I have no idea on that really.

Also if you plan to use Freetrack (again, accuracy) you need to know some electroics. How to solder, how to measure resistance for LED's, that sort of thing. Either that or buy your assembly from someone that does. TrackIR comes with everything you need for around $120.
